Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Virucidal surface coatings for prevention of COVID-19 transmission
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will result from reducing overall COVID-19 mortality, and reducing the incidence of morbid secondary infections in intubated patients such as ventilator-acquired pneumonia (VAP). The market for antifouling/antimicrobial indwelling endotracheal tubes (ETTs) was estimated at $1.85 billion in 2017 with 6.6% annual growth, and further increases are likely due to the outbreaks of COVID-19 and other respiratory diseases. More than 50% of COVID-19 deaths are attributable to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) from secondary healthcare-acquired infections, such as VAP. Unfortunately, ETTs used for ventilation do not prevent bacterial settlement upon their surfaces (biofouling). To date there is only one FDA-approved antimicrobial ETT that does not target fouling as the root cause of VAP, leaving this critical issue unaddressed. The proposed technology advances the development of ETTs with novel coatings and can potentially be used in other indwelling biomedical medical devices, including urinary-, central venous-, and hemodialysis catheters (estimated market size: $77.7 billion by 2026). A ~10% reduction infection rate with this technology could prevent 1.7 million healthcare-acquired infections, annually saving 99,000 lives and $28-45 billion associated-cost in the US. This technology will also support research in antimicrobial interactions with surfaces. <br/><br/>This SBIR Phase I project proposes to establish the feasibility of gemini-surfactant inspired coatings on ETTs to reduce COVID-19 mortality. Current approaches to prevent biofouling in ETTs involve incorporation of biocidal Ag+ ions or deposition of hydrophilic polymers resembling traditional surfactants to the surface. However, such biocide-release coatings liberate Ag+ ions that are cyto- and genotoxic and are subject to gradual depletion of the active agent. Meanwhile, the polymers are limited by both intrinsically hydrophobic regions in their backbones and the low surface activities of conventional “parent” surfactants. This project will advance the development of a new class of antifouling coatings combining structural elements of powerful gemini surfactants displaying surface activities orders of magnitude higher than their conventional counterparts, with the molecularly precise and durable surface modification technique of silanization. By mimicking the structures of gemini surfactants, incorporating multiple ionic “head” groups into the coating via silanization, hydrophilicity and antifouling/antimicrobial properties will be greatly increased relative to conventional antifouling coatings.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background

 As of August 2021, the COVID-19 pandemic has infected at 36.2 million people and claimed the lives of over 618,000 individuals in the United States alone (204 million cases and 4.1 million deaths worldwide) [1]. Despite campaigns to increase public awareness of the importance of vigilant personal hygiene, (masks, social distancing, handwashing, vaccines) the US is still experiencing tens of thousands of new cases with the variants, highlighting the highly infectious nature of the disease. According to the WHO and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), COVID-19 (SARS-CoV-2) is primarily transmitted between people through inhalation/contact with respiratory droplets. Surface-contact (fomite) transmission in high-traffic areas is inevitable with current cleaning methods as current disinfectants are only effective during their application, after which they can become easily re-contaminated in the interim between cleanings. When SARS-CoV-2 settles on surfaces, physical contact with the surface, and then facial mucosa allows viral transmission and infection to occur. Whereas in earlier stages of the pandemic, countries that had achieved mitigation from high masking-compliance, now have begun to experience alarming spikes in transmission despite continued compliance and growing availability of vaccines. Numerous modeling, microbiological, observational, and intervention studies have established that surface contamination is a substantial contributor to the spread of numerous infectious diseases, including SARS-coronaviruses. Surfaces in high-traffic areas are high-risk sources of infection even if cleaned regularly, as asymptomatic patients actively shedding virus can transfer viral material to them in between scheduled cleanings. These sanitization methods generally utilize common disinfectants such as UV light, bleach, hydrogen peroxide, alcohol solutions, and quaternary ammonium surfactants. However, Their established reliability notwithstanding, these agents only disinfect the surface while in contact with the cleaning agent which is either quickly evaporated or wiped away after sanitizing, thus with conventional disinfectants, surfaces are immediately susceptible to re-contamination immediately afterwards. To limit the spread of COVID-19 and other highly infectious pathogens, new strategies enabling surfaces to continuously self-decontaminate (self-disinfecting surfaces), are urgently required.

However, there are no commercially available self-disinfecting coatings that 1) display efficacy comparable to traditional sanitization methods, and 2) have been proven to rapidly and continuously inactivate coronaviruses and pathogenic bacteria.

Technical Accomplishments

 Current approaches to self-disinfecting surfaces involve the use of metal/biocide-release coatings or deposition of quaternary ammonium based polymers.  However, biocides become gradually depleted while the deposition of ionic polymers generates coatings of limited durability. To address these challenges, ACatechol has developed a new class of self-disinfecting coatings that combine structural elements of powerful gemini surfactants, with the durable covalent surface modification technique of silanization to ensure durability.  By mimicking the structures of gemini surfactants and incorporating multiple ionic ?head? groups into the coating, hydrophilicity and antimicrobial properties are greatly increased relative to conventional disinfectant coatings.

The new class of surface modifying disinfectants derived from organosilanes and gemini-surfactants has been developed and evaluated for their ability to endow surfaces with antimicrobial/antiviral activity, as well as their capacity to act as traditional disinfectants. Both disinfection and surface coating with our new gemini diquaternary organosilanes (GQs) were demonstrated to be accomplished with identical and dilute aqueous solutions of these compounds; requiring only a period of drying to maximize durability. Efficacy was shown to be broad against both gram positive and negative bacteria in ISO standard suspension-/surface-antimicrobial activity tests, while solutions/coatings were also effective against SARS-CoV-2. By studying how surfaces antimicrobial activity changes as a function of time, we observed that activity drops off precipitously 5 minutes after application for traditional disinfectants, while GQs? are able to achieve over 99.9999% reductions 24 hours after the last application, remaining active for up to 15 days.

By demonstrating self-sanitizing properties on both non-porous and porous surfaces between cleanings/washings, this gemini quaternary silane disinfectant/surface treatment has the potential to greatly reduce bacterial/viral surface-contact infections, reducing healthcare costs and saving numerous lives each year.

Broader Impact

Our coatings may be implemented clinically to reduce the spread of SARS-CoV-2 on high traffic surfaces. Owing to the surfaces self-disinfecting nature, our coatings will reduce risk of non-compliance/user error of traditional sanitization methods. Not restricted solely to SARS-CoV-2 and its variants, surfaces coated with our technology will additionally prevent the spread of other enveloped viruses and pathogenic bacteria (S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, and E. coli). By continuously killing viruses/bacteria that settle upon the coating, surfaces may be sanitized less frequently minimizing materials and labor costs of sanitization. Compared to traditional disinfectants, the environmental impact is reduced by preventing accumulation of disinfectant residues in wastewater while user safety is improved with simple, dilute, aqueous solutions, avoiding the handling of concentrated disinfectants

 


Last Modified: 08/12/2021
Modified by: Kollbe Ahn
